Award.AwardTitle: NSF Nanoscale Science and Engineering (NSE) 2019 Grantees Conference, To Be Held At The Westin Alexandria, Alexandria, VA, December 9-10, 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Nanoscale Science and Engineering (NSE) 2019 Grantees Conference is a two-day annual event that brings together nanoscale educators, researchers, and experimentalists from academia, government, and industry to highlight information on the research and education activities funded by NSF NSE grants. The primary goals are to promote dissemination of innovative research progress, to facilitate research partnerships, and to identify future research directions. Panel discussions will be moderated by NSF-funded researchers as well as NSF Program Directors. The conference helps advance the goals of the NSF and the U.S. National Nanotechnology Initiative. Conference materials are made available to the wider audience following the event at the website: www.nseresearch.org, along with archival information from previous events.

The NSE grantees conference will foster interaction among academic, government, and industry researchers in nanotechnology fields. Keynote presentations and interactive panel discussions on the grand challenges in and convergence of nanotechnology generate opportunities for creative interdisciplinary collaboration. Identification and exploration of future trends in nanotechnology and cyberinfrastructure enable researchers and industry to prepare to fully capitalize on next-generation capabilities. The first day of the conference will focus on Progress in foundational nanotechnology and infrastructure: Nanoscale processes in neural systems; AI confluence with nanoscale modeling, design and systems; Quantum phenomena in nanobio and environmental systems, Cell Nanocomponents and Synthetic Biology, Nanomachines; and Nano research centers, NNCI and Nano-HUB. The second day will feature Grand opportunities and convergence: Nanosustainability and Nanoplastics in Environment; Nano- biosensing; Metamaterials; Nano-Geosciences and convergence; Convergence approaches - accelerators; Convergence Learning challenges; and Societal and environmental aspects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
2019 National Science Foundation Nanoscale Science and Engineering Grantees Conference

Summary of Project Outcomes

The 2019 Nanoscale Science and Engineering (NSE) Grantees Conference on Progress in Nanotechnology featured presentations and panels that highlighted state-of-the-art nano-STEM research, sustainable nanotechnology, and related educational activities and ethical considerations. The December 9-10 Conference promoted networking and interdisciplinary synergies among the more than 150 participating scientists and engineers from academia, government and industry, with expertise spanning a diverse array of nanotechnology fields. It served as a forum that bridged several disciplines and encouraged collaborations, especially between the physical and biological sciences. The high attendance reflected the importance and timely nature of the Conference themes and session topics.

 

The first day's theme, Progress in foundational nanotechnology and infrastructure, covered topics that included Artificial Intelligence and nanoscale simulations and design; Nanoscale processes and neural systems; International dimensions of science and engineering research; Quantum phenomena in biological and environmental systems; Cell nanocomponents and synthetic biology; Nanomachines; Nano-research centers, i.e., The National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI) - Research Triangle Nanotechnology Network (RTNN), Midscale research opportunities at the National Science Foundation (NSF), Centers for Chemical Innovation (CCI) - Center for Sustainable Nanotechnology, and The Engineering Research Center for Environmentally Benign Semiconductor Manufacturing, an example of convergence in the NSF's ERC program; as well as an Overview of the nanoHUB and its role in nanoinformatics. Day 2 emphasized Grand opportunities and convergence in nanotechnology and focuses on topics that ranged from Research challenges for nanoplastics in the environment, Nanotechnology for sustainability, and Societal and ethical aspects of nanotechnology to Nano-biosensors, Metamaterials, and Nanoscale geosciences and convergence to Nanotechnology education and outreach, which included a discussion on the NSF's plans for the Convergence Accelerator program and the role of education in that program. The poster sessions fostered in-depth conversations with team representatives from the twenty-nine accepted posters, as well as additional discussions of the Conference presentations. At this year's Conference, the NNCI community provided a significant number of the exhibited posters and demonstrated significant the synergy across the clusters.

 

Based on the oral and poster presentations, follow-on discussions and networking activities, the Conference delivered a key message that the Nano platform and infrastructure continues to catalyze, support and serve as a critical enabler for many emergent and convergent technologies. Interested readers may access the oral and poster presentations, along with presenter and moderator bios and abstracts at the following URL: http://www.nseresearch.org/2019/ .
